en: Tornac (Tornagus in Gallo-Roman times) has a rich historical heritage that is still present today. The partially destroyed Monastery was the seat of an abbey founded in the 7th century by Benedictine monks affiliated to the Order of Cluny around 1080. Ruined in the 8th century, it came under the protection of Charlemagne on the 9th and was ruined again in the 16th century. Private property, it is visible from the outside. The castle of Tornac (11th and 12th centuries) It overlooks the right bank of the Gardon d'Anduze at a strategic location which allowed it to protect the entrance to Anduze and the Cévennes. It offers an exceptional panoramic view of Anduze and the Tornac vineyard, which comprises about 200 hectares cultivated in "organic farming" to produce "organic" wines of growing renown. The Tornac winegrowers' cellar is open every day, except Sundays; open days with guided tours of the cellar are organised every Friday in July and August. The Saint-Baudile Church Erected in the 12th century, it is in Romanesque style, in the shape of a Latin cross, with a semicircular apse crowned with arches. Destroyed in the 16th century, rebuilt in the 17th century, burnt in 1702, it was restored at the end of the last century and is listed as a Historic Monument. Numerous hiking routes are available to walkers: the Ourne Valley from the church of Saint-Baudile through the Monastery, the source of Fontfroide to the Moulin du Baron. The "Sens" trail is a sensitive 13 km walk, lasting 3 hours without any great difficulty, through Tornac, its hamlets and the many sites or vestiges of its historical heritage. Several gîtes and guest rooms are there to welcome you and make your stay in Tornac easier. Whatever the season, it should satisfy all lovers of history, preserved heritage and magnificent landscapes. Welcome to Tornac.
fr: Tornac (Tornagus à l’époque gallo-romaine) est riche d’un patrimoine historique encore présent aujourd’hui. Le Monastère partiellement détruit, était le siège d’une abbaye fondée au VIIe siècle par des moines bénédictins affiliés à l’ordre de Cluny vers 1080. Ruiné au VIIIe siècle, il passe sous la protection de Charlemagne au 9 et est ruiné une nouvelle fois au 16 siècle. Propriété privée, il est visible de l’extérieur. Le château de Tornac  (XIe et XIIe siècles) Il surplombe la rive droite du Gardon d’Anduze à un emplacement stratégique qui lui permettait de protéger l’entrée vers Anduze et les Cévennes. Il offre une vue panoramique exceptionnelle sur Anduze et sur le vignoble de Tornac qui comprend environ 200 hectares cultivés en « agriculture biologique » pour produire des vins « bio » à la renommée grandissante. La cave des vignerons de Tornac est ouverte tous les jours, sauf le dimanche ; des journées « portes ouvertes » avec visite guidée de la cave sont organisées tous les vendredis en juillet et août. L’Église Saint-Baudile Érigée au XIIe siècle, elle est de style roman, en forme de croix latine, avec une abside en demi-cercle couronnée d’arceaux. Détruite au XVIe siècle, reconstruite au XVIIe, brûlée en 1702, elle a été restaurée à la fin du siècle dernier et est inscrite aux Monuments Historiques. De nombreux itinéraires de randonnées s’offrent aux promeneurs : la Vallée de l’Ourne à partir de l’église Saint-Baudile en passant par le Monastère, la source de Fontfroide jusqu’au Moulin du Baron. Le parcours « Sens » est une promenade sensitive de 13 km, d’une durée de 3  heures sans grosse difficulté, à travers Tornac, ses hameaux et les nombreux sites ou vestiges de son patrimoine historique. Plusieurs gîtes et chambres d’hôtes sont là pour vous accueillir et vous faciliter un séjour sur Tornac qui, quelle que soit la saison, devrait satisfaire tous les amateurs d’Histoire, de patrimoine préservé et de paysages magnifiques. Bienvenue à Tornac.

en:
Tornac (Tornagus in Gallo-Roman times) has a rich historical heritage that is still present today.
The Monastery
partially destroyed, was the seat of an abbey founded in the 7th century by Benedictine monks affiliated to the Cluny order around 1080. Ruined in the 8th century, it came under the protection of Charlemagne in the 9th and was ruined again in the 16th century. Private property, it is visible from the outside.
The castle of Tornac (11th and 12th centuries) It overlooks the right bank of the Gardon d'Anduze in a strategic location that allowed it to protect the entrance to Anduze and the Cevennes. It offers an exceptional panoramic view of Anduze and the Tornac vineyards, which cover about 200 hectares and are cultivated using organic methods to produce increasingly renowned organic wines. The Tornac winegrowers' cellar is open every day except Sunday; open days with guided tours of the cellar are organised every Friday in July and August.
The Church of Saint-Baudile
Built in the 12th century, it is Romanesque, in the form of a Latin cross, with a semi-circular apse crowned with arches. Destroyed in the 16th century, rebuilt in the 17th century, burnt down in 1702, it was restored at the end of the last century and is listed as a Historic Monument. There are many walking routes: the Ourne Valley from the church of Saint-Baudile through the Monastery, the source of Fontfroide to the Moulin du Baron. The "Sens" route is a sensitive walk of 13 km, lasting 3 hours with no great difficulty, through Tornac, its hamlets and the many sites or vestiges of its historical heritage. Several gites and guest houses are there to welcome you and make your stay in Tornac easier. Whatever the season, it should satisfy all lovers of history, preserved heritage and magnificent landscapes. Welcome to Tornac.
